div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hedeirab. Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah at call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Vain Protest.
div.p: Our Port Said contemporary, "La Verite." complains of the high rents and prices prevailing, and invokes the Government to regulate this cost.

div.head: Tour Eiffel Music Hall.
div.p: As already announced, there will be a special perfomance at this hall tonight for the benefit of the crew of the Italian curiser Calambria. After the performance there will be a masked ball.

div.head: Planoforte Recital.
div.p: A pianoforte recital will be given at the New Khedivial Hotel tomorrow afternoon at 5 o'clock by M. Cairo Angelelli who submits an excellent programme which space forbids our publishing. Tickets may be had at the hotel price P.T. 40.

div.head: Mosque for the Lebanon.
div.p: A gorup of Egyptian Moslems has decided to open a list of subscrivers for the construction of a mosque at Alei, in the Lebanon. "Al Minbar" publishes a list of notables of the Dessouk district who have subscribed L.E. 50 for this purpose.

div.head: Ottoman Anniversary.
div.p: The banquet appointed for tonight at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo in celebration of the foundation of the Ottoman Empire, has been adjourned till tomorrow, when it will be substituted by five o'clock tes, and this in order to satisfy a large number of subscribers.

div.head: Female Education in Egypt.
div.p: Saad Pasha Zaghloul's recent speech a Tahta in favour of female education appears to have around considerable interest in native circles. The Pasha strongly urged the necessity for Moslems to bestir themselves in this important question, and declared that female education was essential to the future progress of Egypt.

div.head: Anti-Russian Bias.
div.p: Quite a large number of people have returned tickets for the Russian ball in Cairo, regardless of the fact that the proceeds are to go in aid of the refugees from Russia. M. Smyruoff. The Russian Agent, has admirably reproved this unreasonable prejudice by placing himself at the head of the relief committee, which has heaby calls upon its offers from the unhappy Hebrews in Cairo.

div.head: Imperial Birthday.
div.p: The Kaiser celebrates his 48th birthday tomorrow, and in honour of the event a recpetion will be held at the German Agency in Cairo, and at the German Consulate in Alexandria. A thanksgiving service will be held in the Protestant Church, rue de la Poste, and the day's festivities include school treats and an amateur performance at the Eiffel Tower Theatre organised by the members of the German Sporting Club.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Phen of Siam and a numerous suite arrived at Port Said on Thursday last by the German S.S. Prince Eitel Friedrich. He is on his way to ROme to make the necessary prepartaions there for the visit of King Chulalongkom of Siam to Italy.
M. Klobakowski leaves Cairo at 7 a.m. on Monday for Port Said, where he will embark for Europe.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AGITATION. ACTION OF AUTHORITIES.
div.p: Alexandria has ever since Sunday preserved a most tranquil appearance, and there seems to be no sign that there will be any recrudescence of the turbulent scenes such as disturbed the public peace of Egypt's commercial capital on Saturday and Sunday last. The Alexandria City Police are, however, perpared for any eventualities, and all the mouonted police and all the guard company are kept constantly under orders in case of trouble and are ready to be turned out in the short space of three minutes. But it is most sincerely to be hoped that in the interests of the whole country tranquillity may be considered to be completely restored. It is still thought advisable, however, to have a strong guard of police at the Russian Consulate.

Lord Cromer has replied to the members of the committee who presented his Lordship with the petition which we published in our issue of Thursday last. Lord Cromer's reply is unfavorable, as was only to be expected.

"I do not see my way," his Lordship said, "to advise the Egyptian Government to abstain from the surrendering of the Russian subjects to their Consul to be treated in accordance with Russian law. the treaty of 1774 does not seem to me to be applicable to the case in question and the Government are only doing their duty.

"My personal opinion is well known, and I deem that none of the privileges conferred by the Capitulations for the protection of foreigners should be abolished, but I consider that certain modifications should be introduced into the present regime.
"At any rate is is clear that until such modifications are approved by the Powers and put in force, it is necessary to enforce the law just as it is in every respect."
The Russian Consular authorities at Alexandria will send off the three men, Botsoff, Shureen, and Vopula, to their own country as soon as it is considered necessary.

In all probability the Russian Consulate here will lodge a formal complaint at the French Consulate against M. Raoul Canivet on the grounds that he excited the agitation by publishing misstatements. The Russian consular authorities declare that the allegations that the men are accused of plotting, and whatever punishment be moved out to them when they reach their native land they certainly will not be condemned to capital punishment.

If any definite evidence is obtained by the Russian consular authorities by the other persons who are considered to have been the ringleaders, they will also lodge complaints agaisnt them at the consulates on which they depend.

It was announced by the leaders of the agitation that the enquiry was already closed, and that the men were to be "despatched at once to Russia." This statement wasm we understand quite false as it reposed on no foundation of fact at all.

The authorities of the Alexandria Gonvernorat intend to take proceedings at the British Consular Court here against Mr. William Patrick Foley, a British subject, who was arrested for having taken part in the outrage at the Russian Consulate last Sunday. Foley was arrested, but has been released on bail. The Alexandria City Police accuse this man of being at the head of the demonstrators and of having encouraged them. He is also said by the police to have been one of the men rushed upon the door to the consulate and pulled down the coat-of-arms above the door, and also attempted to break it. When Yousbashi Mussa Effendi and Constable John Iken tried to prevent him, he turned on them and assaulted them.

Mr. Paul Manse, the editor of "L'Orient," in a leading article on the recent demonstation, makes the following just observations: "The extraordinary part of it is that all this disturbance should be organised, fomented, and kept up for forty-eight hours by those who under all circumstances have insissted on the integral maintenance of the Capitualtions... It is a matter of deep regret that the Egyptian Government should be held responsible, and be obliged to demand excuses for the faults of unauthrosed persons instigated by those who sought an object particularly inadmissible in this land where respect of the faith of others must be the first rule. But it would be so easy to say that the thousand, and one manifestants of Alexandria and Cairo do not represent any serious opinion in Egypt, and that they do not even represent their own. Don't talk of an immoderate love of liberty, or of a burning passion for equity. Where were these orators, these enegetic manifestations of last week when Egyptians were being hanged at Denishwai: Without judegment or criticism, it was then that they mighht have carried out their philanthropy in pleading for the pardon or poor devils no less worthy of their attention.… The real victims of all this noise are the three Russian prisoners themselves who will not evidently benefit by special leniency after all this to-do organised by our Egyptian liberals.

div.head: ROYAL VISIT. RECEPTION AT KHEDIVIAL HOTEL.
div.p: The reception given at the New Khedivial Hotel yesterday afternoon by the Italian colony in honour of H.R.H. the Prince of Udina was an unqualified success. A large number of invitations had been issued, and the alrge and fashionable gathering that was timed to commence at 4 o'clock and that hour his Royal Highness arrived at the hotel, in company of the Marquis di Soragna. Italian Consul, being greeted by the strains of the Italian national anthem, played by a band stationed at the entrance. Shortly after the Prince's arrival, the members of the Consular Corps were presented to him by the Marquis di Soragns, and afterwards dancing commenced in the magnificent ballrooms of the hotel, his Royal Highness opening the ball with Miss Stagni as his partner. Dancing continued all the afternoon, the Royal guest remaining an interesteed spectator almost to the end. A well stocked buffet was provided in the dining-room, which, as also the adjoining ante-room, was tastefully decorated and illuminated. The music for the dancing was furnished by Heckmayer's orchestra, and the hotel orchestra also played selections downstairs. The committee are to be congratulated on the success of the arragnements of what was altogether a charming fete.
This morning H.E. the Governor paid an official visit to the cruiser Calabria, accompanied by his seretary, Beneducci Bey.
In the evening, the crew of the Calabria will be entertained at the Tour Eiffel Music Hall. It is expected that the Prince will honour the entertainment with his presence.
The Prince will pay a visit tomorrow to the Alexandria bbranch of the Banco di Roma.
Tomorrow afternoon a reception will be held on board the cruiser for the Italian colony.
The Calabria leaves for Italy on Monday.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will come down to Alexandria tomorrow.
The customary Kourban-Beyram visits were exchanged between his Highness and Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha.

div.head: SEASON AT HELOUAN. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: Helouan, Friday.

Though small, Helouan boasts of a thoroughly sporting community; and in these days of Beyram when every hotel has been full, there has been a continual round of amusements among the inhabitants and visitors. In fact, life is Helouan is a very socialbe business, for people stay there long enough, as a rule, to become thoroughly acquainted with each other; and the rivalry between the hotels is of a very friendly nature. Miss Tottenham and Miss Moore have been two of the leading spirits in the organizing of the long programme of sports and amusements which has kept all the more youthful and energetic members of society but these last few days. A tennis tournament has provided interest during the day, while a bridge tournament has occupied the evening hours. The donkey paper chase has been well, attended, and a picnic to Wady HOf provided a reason for another outing.

The Grand Hotel was the scene of a most enjoyable dance last night, the handsome dining hall being transformed into a very roomy and beuatiful ball-room with a parquet floor in the very pink of condition. Music was supplied by the Sextet orchestra, which was so much appreciated at Mena House the preceding night, and to its performance on both occassions must be attributed much of the success of these dances. There was a delightful air of friendliness over the whole proceedings, and never a trace of boredom from first to last: and though the last few dances had to be somewhat hurried (time and trainns waiting for no one) there was no trace of fatigue visible in the movements of those who had filled their programmes.

It is not possible to give a complete list of all of those who were present; but among those who were present were noticed Mr. and Mrs. Beasley, Mr. and Mrs. Sharman, Mrs. Charlton (who came with a party from Cairo) Mrs. Mackintosh Walker, Mrs. Ashley Cock, Mrs. Murch, Mrs.Logan. Miss Hobson, Miss Key, Miss Reid, Miss White, Miss Carter, Miss Ashuret, Miss Paytono, Miss Moore, Miss Tottenham, Miss Broderick, the Misses Bentley, Miss Hazel, and Miss Darley. As it is still more difficult to enumerate the gentlemen who graced the occasion with their presence, perhaps they will excuse any mention of their names. They did their duty manfully and well and with a vigour that must assuredly be the result of the wonderful air and healthy life of Helouan.
There is to be a second dance at the Tewfik Palace Hotel on Saturday which promises to be an equal success, and will doubtless prove a very fitting termination to a very delightful week's enjoyment.

div.head: ZIZANIA THEATRE.
div.p: On Thursday evening there was yet another and meritorious performance of "La Dannezione di Faust." Especially noticeable were the exertions of Sigri, Marcolin, and Berriel, both of whom managed to infuse more colour into their roles; there was much more "go" about Sig. Berriel's Mefistofele, while Sig. Maronlin was quite at his best in the wonderfully inspring "invocation to nature" scene. Signa Grisi again made a satisfactory Margherita. Abundant praise is once more due to the admirable way in which Maestro Zuccani handled his orchestra. Their playing from first to last was a real pleasure. The chorus were a trifle out of hand in the first two scences but the fugue scene 3 was more than ever admirably rendered, and from the onwards they behaved most creditably. We have furthermore to be deeply and humbly grateful for some curtailment iin the entr' actors but we hesitate to dwell upon the matter lest advantage be taken of it and we be mulcted once more in waits of half-an-hour or so.

There is little to be said for last night's production of "Gli Ugonotti." A fair mediocrity was maintained, but not without difficulty. The oepra is so very "vieux jeu" that iin order to work up one's enthusiasm it requires to be given in a more artistic and finished style than was the case yesterday. Nearest to this consummation came Signa Chotkowska in her impersonation of the page Urbano, and Sig. Walter, who was again thoroughly convincing in his spirited role of Marcello. Sig de Marchi was jerky and nassal, but we must patiently wait until his cold has left him ere we venture a comment on his abilities. The chorus and orchestra were fair, but on the whole performance fell far short of that of the previous night and often failed to hold the attention.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit within certain necessary limits free discussion.
VICTORIA COLLEGE
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, In references to a letter in yesterday's issue from a gentleman, who is admittedly a casual observer. I do not feel called upon to enter into a newspaper controversy with an anonymous contributor to your columns, but if your correspondent causes to give me a call at my office I shall be happy to furnish him with information on the subject, which will enable himi to revise his facts and no doubt modigy his judgement. Yours truly,
ARTHUR S. PRESTON,
Honorary secretary, Victoria College

div.head: K.S.C. SECOND WINTER MEETING.
div.p: Yesterday, for the second day's racing of the Second Winter Meeting, we had to face another cold day and cold wind, and occasional showers of rain added to the discomfort. Everyone, however, who came seemed prepared for Arctic weatherm and made the best of it. The attendance was considerably better than on the first day; and the racing was mostly excellent. Tokar's win in the Eclipse was a great surprise. This little horse is game the backbone, and has been running very steadily throughout the season. Suleik, in this race tried to cut it in the run in and spoilt Jenkin's chance. This last named jockey rode an excellent race on the same horse in the Galloway Handicap. In the United Service Steeplechase Mr. de Freville rode with great skill and judgment. Making his effort at the right time he won comfortably. Capt Collum, in the same race, had bad luck, Richmond coming down when going strong. The rider escaped with the loss of some skin, but the horse was taken off in the ambulance to the infirmary with a badly sprained shoulder.

The handicapping worked out excellently. Not every one knows the difficulties and loss of time connected with this part of racing, and we may congratulate our handicapper on his success throughout the season. About 2,000 changed hands at the pari Mutnel.
The following are particulars of the racing:-
THE KHEDIVIAL HANDICAP. For Arab ponies. Value L.E. 40. 2nd horse to receive L.E. 3, if four or more start, and 3rd horse L.E. 2, if six or more start, out of the stakes. Distance 1 1/7 mile.

div.head: THE JAMAICA INCIDENT. REPORTED RESIGNATION OF GOVERNOR.

div.p: It has transpired that Admiral Davis was expressly requeseted to land men by the Colonial Secretary and by the Inspector of Constabulary, who feared trouble with the convicts. Hence the Governor's protest is difficult to understand.
According to a well-accredited report, Sir J. Swettenham has tendered his resignation. (R.)

div.head: EVACUATION OF MANCHURA. RUSSIA ANTICIPATES DATE.

div.p: Russia has notified China and Japan of her decision to evacuate Manchuria forthwith instead of waiting for the appointed date of the 15th of April next. (Reuter)
The polling has opened for the elections. The weather is extremely cold.
A heavy poll is being taken throughout the whole of Germnay. The Socialists are splendidly organised and are using the most strenous exertions.
The elections to the Reichstag have taken palce without any incident. The Socialists have gained the majority of seats in Berlin. Havas.
The split on the Religious Associations BIll led to the resignation of the Liberal Cabinet. Senor Maura has formed a Conservative Ministry. (Reuter)

Sir H. Campbell-Bannermarn, receiving the freedom of the city, dealt lengthily with the question of social problems. He said that municipalities could rely upon Parliament for help in their social work. "What is the use of wealth and learning." he said, "if the great labouring classes are doomed to live and die in darkness and misery?" He emphasized that it was not foreign missions but our own people that had the first claim. (Reuter)

The Lord Advocate Shaw, speaking at Edinburgh hinted at the possibility of a resolutiono being borught into the House of Commons next session limiting the rights of the Peers to a single sessiono in the case of the veto of a Bill. If this is ignoredm then a Bill should be passed entitling vetoed measures to be submitted to Royal assent if they again passed the Commons (Reuter)
The Senate has passed the Budget. (Havas)

div.head: A SUGGESTION TO EGYPTIANS. NATIONAL EDUCATION.
div.p: An "Echo" of "Orient and Occident" has been issued as a supplement to this weekly illustrated Anglo-Arabic magazine. Under the heading of the "Problem of National Education," we read:-

It is hoped that this review will be of use to those in Egypt who are showing so marked an interest in the more general education of their fellow countrymen. It will be readily seen that the interantional and religious problem is just as pressing here as it is in India and America, while there is in Egypt a national spirit which is making itself felt in a hundred ways from time to time. The puzzle, of couse, consists in how to secure a national sttlement of the educational question, which would be accpetable to both Moslems and Copts, and will respect the fact that Egypt is also the home to many nationalities.

It is of the utmost importance, in a small country like Egypt, which has a population not bigger than that of England a hundred years ago, that there should be a growing national spirt fostreefdd by a national educational system. On the other hand it is equally necessary to respect the consciences of the several freligious bodies, and to see to it that mistkaes which have been made in India and in Japan are not reapeated here in Egypt. The only way in which a nation can avoid seeing its sons growing up without morality and religion is to make due provision in its educational system that both he taught. There are only two fair ways discovered, in which a State, which professes to be governed by the principles of libertly, equality, and fraternity to men of all races, classes and creeds, can secure a moral and religious education for its children: neither of which are incompatible with the existence of an established religion such as Islam in Egypt or Christianity in England. The one way is to subsidize all schools of whatever religious foundation which come up to a certain educational standard, by paying for the worht of their secular education given, but not makind distinctions between the merits of anhy particular form of religious teaching. The other method is to allow (what is called0 a right of entry to teachers of different religious bodies into all schools under government inspection in order to teach the children of different denominations in each school the faith of their parents if they so desire it.

These two solutions are by no means exclusive, and can be adopted simultaneously n the case of differnty types of schools. For instance, Govern,ent schools in Egypt should, if what has been said is just, admit teachers of Christianity to Christian pupils, just as they encourage the right of entry to Mohamedan teachers for Moslem pupils. And in the case of the many Moslem, Christian, and Jewish voluntary schools in Egypt which are everywhere springing up, the Egyptian Government would if it follow the example of Engalnd and other progressive Eastern nations, encourage the same by means of grants in aid in spite of their particular denominational complexion,

The following are some of the beneficial results which are likely to follow. In the first place it would hasten the day when everry boy and girl in Egypt will at least reveive a fair vernacular education. IT would both increase the desire for ecuation among all classes, and the liberality of those who are albe to found schools to meet that desire. It would develop the spirit of patriotism, and yet make all classes of people in Egypt feel that the Education Department is in full sympathy with their aspirations. And finally it would have the practical and desirable effect of rasining up a generation of men, who would be better qualifed and trained for public service and private enterprises.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN ARMY. REQUIREMENTS OF THE SUDAN.
div.p: The ordinary Budget of the Egyptian Ministry of War for 1907 shows an increase of 72,388, while special ore lits amounting to 56,596 are to be opened during the year. It need not be said that the Government of the Sudan, where the greater part of the Egyptian army is stationed has no aggressive intentions. Its relations with Abyssinia are excellent; and the annual rumours, doubtless fostered by mischiefmakers, of an approaching conflict with Dar Fur have at last died a natural death. Sultan Ali Dinar has nothing to fear from Khartoum as long as he pays his yearly tribute and respects the frontier of Kordofan tribute and respects the frontier of Kordofan.

On the other hand, the gradual extension of Government influence over the wilder and more remote districts of the Sudan cannot be effected without an increase in the forces the disposal of the Sirdar. This is especially the case in South Eastern Kordofan, where tribal warfare still persists between the "Meks," or chiefs, of the numerous isolated mountains that are the most striking natural feature of that region. The Nubas of those mountains resided for the last half-century by the nomad Arabs, the Dervish forces, Zebehr's Bazingers, and the troops of the old Government, are as and the troops of the old Government, are as suspicious as they are turbulent. Many of their mounatins are unknown to Europeans, and mounatins are unknown to Europeans and their "Meks," relieved, thanks to the Government. And finally it would have the practical and desirable effect of raising up a generation of men, who would be better qualified and trained for public service and private enterprises.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE Cotons.
div.p: Decidement l'absurds commence a prendre droit de cite a notre conbeille, car nous voila de nouveau l'objet d'attaques violentes, appuyees sur de pures calomnies. Et le plus bean est que ce deversement de mauvaise humeur contre nos idees de baisse provient de la part de gens qui ne peuvent exciper ni de leur ignorance, ni de leur marque d'educatoino, mais qui representent peut-etre le menu fretin de la specualtion a la hausee. Au fond, et malgre els inquietudes qu'elles peuvent nous inspirer sur l'etat d'esprit de xeux qui s'y livrent, ces crialleries nous laissent parfaitement indifferents et ne nous em, echeront jamais de continuer a soutenir notre opinion tant que nour croirons etre dans le vrai, quitte a faire amende honorable des que nous lous apercevrons etre dans l'erreur, ainai, charitablement, nous conseillerions a ces exaltes, qui croiant changer le cours des evenmeuts par des paroles, de reflechir sur leur maniero d'agir. Cela leur eviterait de a a'offrir en spectacle au public des qu'une application a point de 500 on 1,000 Cantars vient produire sur eux l'effetd'une douche sur un systems nerveux surexcite, en les faissant battre en retraite d'une facon plutot comique.
Dix.

La tenue de notre marche pendant la se maine qui vient de fior, a etre du tout au tout differente de celle dout nous avons rendu compte dans notre precedente revue. An lieu de la fern etre qui n'avait cease de regner, aves une finale toutefois peu brillante, c'ete une serie de seances faibles, avec des cours une serie de seances faibles, avec des cours chaque jour en baisse sur la veille, que nous avons eue,, mais avec un revirement soudain a la derniere heure pour ainsi dire accompagne d'une reprise s'elevant a 13 32 surle minimum de la semsine pratique ce matin. Le contraste a donc etre compelt. Qiant au resultant materiel a donc etre complet. Quiant au resultant materialobtenn depuis vendredi dernier, il consistre en une baisse de 5/16 en tout et pour etre juste, il font reconnaitre que o'est grace au savoirfaire du parti haussier que l'on doit que les choses se soient arretees a ce point. Les improd onte qui se sont amuses a vendre en blanu au moment du desarrio et qui and tout semblait fini, ont fourni cette fois des armes a leurs adversaires, qui les out retournees contreeux, et comme le Caire qui avait commence a inspirer des inquietudes par son attitiude, et mene encourage les baissiers par son hesitation est revenu anssi tout a coup a la rescousse, le jeu des haussiers a etre facile. Il est toutefois de fait que nons noustrouvons tout bonnement en face d'une chose accidentelle et provisoirs.

En offet, la situation en elle meme n'a pas change au fond et nous ajousterons meme que les motifs qui millitaient en faveur de la baisse se sont encore aggraves non par la defection d'un gros faisseur, car il n'existait aucon accord, mais par la liquidiation que l'on dit complete de as position a la hausse, ce qui enleve aux autres l'appui precieux qui'iLleur fournissait grace a l'importance de ses operations.

A part cels, il y a aussi de temps a autre des allegemetns, car les personnes qui commencent a se laisser impressionner par lea signes apparents et les assertions d'une prochaine diminuition des exportations comparees a clles de l'annes passee sont nombreuses, sans compter que les arbitragistes continuent a trouver une marge suffisante et amplement remuneratice entre les cours du spot etdes contrats. C'est trop a la fois pour une speculation plus que surchargee et qui ne peut continuer ad libitum a absorber tout ce qui s'offre a la vente. Ce dernier point constitue un danger reel pour le speculateur, qui ne saurait que faire de la marchandise effective on face de laquelle il va se trouver, maia sur cette eventualite nous nous sommes deja assez etendus quand nous avons signa e la chose, et par consequent nous considerous qu'il serait oiseux de nous y arreter de nonveau ou de faire des redites.

En somme, notra avis est toujowrs le meme: la situation actuelle est factice et tant que la consommation ne sera pas revenue au marche pour nous enlever la plus grande partie du solde de notre recolte, il ne peut y avoir aucun espoir seriouc pour une hausee basee. Pour la moment elle s'abstient et cela d'autant plus facilement que ses retraits jusqu'ici et ses achata pour plus tard lui permettront d'aller longtemps de l'avant sans avoir besoin de se laisser imposer des cours extrabagants, meme pour des circumstances exceptionnelles.

Mainteuant, malgre tout ce que nous venous de dire, nous ne voulons pse pretendre que tout est deja perdu; non, car le parti de la hausse peut encore lutter et il repetera tres probablement ses tentatives, et peut etre meme avec des reussites momentanees: mais comme nous l'avons expose plus haut, il n'y a plus de cohesion ou d'unanimite dans les vues des detenteurs de contrats, et a moins de l'imprevuou du secours efficase de la filature, la finale, a une date plus ou moins e oignes, sera celle que nous avons toujours soutenue depuirs les exagerations de la speculation, c'est a dire mauvaire et tres regrettable pour ceux qui se sont engage dans la voie de la hause a des prix etreves. Du reste, le Caire surtout doit se rappe'er de la famuse annee de l'eau, qui lui semblait si propice et qui a fini par laisser des souvenirs si pen desirables.

La tendance du marche est indeciss, mais difficilement il pourrait en etre autrement avec cette lutte acharnee entre haussiers et baisiers; avec la situation de l'americain, la balance semble vouloir pencher du cote de ces derniers.

Comme activite la vieille recolte n'a paslaisse trop a desirer; du raste, l'agitation meme du marche a provogue un developpement des affaires; seulement pour ce qui est de la nouvelle il en a ete un peu autrement les acheteurs du Novembre n'ayant trouve l'occasoin d'intervenir et de manipuler qu'au jourd'hui et a partir du moment que les detenteurs du Mars ont serieusement commence a reagir. De la sorte ils ont evite de se surcharger, tout en reusissant a relever le cours, tache plus facile qu'on ne le croit avec le gros decouver existant sur la prochaine recolte. En tous car, le minimum pratique pour le Novembre a ete de 18 9/32 et la cloture s'en est faite ce soir sur la cote de 18 7/16 soit en tout un recul de 3/32 pour la huitaine.

La derniere fil ere de janvier s'est eleves a 19,250 cantars et n'a pas exerce le moindre effet sur le marche; elle etait reportes ou classee d'avance et en definitive elle a l'air de n'avoir ete mise en circulation que pour faciliter et completer le reglement de la position en contrats qui existait sur le mois courant.

Le janvier donne lieu a quelques receptions, mais, cemme deja dit, il ne s'agit pas dans l'estace d'affaires speculatives, mais simplement d'operations de reports. Sans cette circonstance la difference entre Janvier et mara serait restee d'un tallari au lieu de tombber a 5/8 ou 11/16. C'est toujours un soulagment pour le marche. Les reports ne varient pas beasucoup; ils montrent cependant une tendance a s'elargir.

Comme nouvlles interessantes du dehors, nous en avons en deux xes jours ci. Le rapport du Census Bureau et la derniere estimation d'Ellison de la consommation mondiale a balles 12,370,000 en coton american. Le premier avec son chiffre de 12,168,00 balles egrenees au 15 Janvier n'a pas emu le public, qui a'attendait a peu pres a une quantite pareille, et quant a la seconde, elle a passe presque insperque pour notre marche.

LETTER from Sir Rudolph von Slatin.

Dear Mr. Ward, - Your delightful and most interesting book on the Soudan has reached me. I congratulate you heartily ono the excellent manner in which the work is written and illustrated. All of us who have done our little best to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have received more than kind treatment at your hands... I don't suppose anyone realises more than I do the change that has come over the Sudan since my old and tyrannical master the Khalifa disapperared from the scene. Your description of the Peace and Progress is, in fact, a sequel to my Fire and Sword in the Sudan.
With kindest regards believe me, Yours sincerely,
Rudolf V. Slatin.
London JOHN MURRAY Cairo F. Dimmer

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Les transactions du debut ont eu si peu d'importance que la Corportaion des agents de change n'a pas cru perdre grand'chose en chomant les trois derniers jours de la semaine, a l'occasion des fetes du Courban Bairam. Le fait est qu'en presence d'une tension monetaire deja longue et indefiniment prolongee par le pullulement des emissions nouvelles, on commence a battre froid aux valeurs que la specualtion a trop pour se rejeter prudemment sur d'austres plus solides et juiqui'lci depreciees qui, outre une plus-value eventuelle appreciable, n'exposent pas leurs detenteurs a de desagreables surprises. Aussi, ces dernieres, nom seulement n'ont pas suivi la baisse generale, mais out fait preuve d'une fermete remaquable et donne lieu a une demande discrete et suivie.

Tes samedi, les valuers spculatives qui avaient le plus profite de la recente hausse, sont les premieres a subir les coupa de la reaction. Peu d'affaires d'aillerus, et disreminees sur toute la cote. En revaunche les bonnes valeurs jusques la deprecides, telles que l'Agricols at l'Union Fonciere, teudent a se consolider. Meme aspect lundi et mardi: les affaires se limitent.

Les Joussainces Eaux du Caire perdent 4 francs a 20, alni que la Cassa di Sconto a 277 l''ancienne et 272 la nouvelle, la fondatuer Comptoir 3 livres a 103, la building lands 3/16 a 6 ¼. Les titres suivants perdent respectivment 1/8: la National Bank a 28 1/8, la Ramleh a 6 3/8 l'Alexandria Water a 13 ½, la Daira a 17 3/8, l'Anglo-American Nile a 5 ½ l'action Comptoir a 8, le Credit Franco Egyptien a 6 3/8 et l'Auto-Transport a 4 7/8. En reaction encore les Privilegiees Tramways a 200, les actions Eaux du Caire a 122, la Behera a 41, les Estates a 2 19/32. Sur les autres valuers les varioations sont insignifianter.

Le coupon de l'Agricole ne pourra etre fixe de facon precise qu'a l'epoque de l'Assemblee Generale qui dolt blentot avoir lieu; mais on assure de bonnes source qu'il sera notablement superieur a celui de l'ances deruilers, qui etait de 7 shellings 6 pence.

L'inauguration du Winter Palace Hotel, apparteneant a la societe des Upper Egypt Hotels a ete occasion des louanges unanimes de la Presse pour l'excellent direciton de de cette societe; ce qui n'a rien d'etonnant, lorsque le Conseil d'administation se compose de noms tels que E.A. Harrisou, Ch. Bachler, G. Nungovich, Cook, Pagnon, etc. Le succes obtenu pas les Egyptian et les Nungovich Hotels nous sont un garant du succes des Upper Egypt. La souscription aux 22,000 actions, decides par l'assemblee generale extraordinaire, aura lieu du 4 au 6 Fevrier et sera reservee aux anciens porteurs dans la proportion de 2 actions nonvelles conotre 5 anciennes.

En ce qui concerne les previsions, sauf les reserves que nous avous faiates au comne cement de notre chronique, l'avenir se presente sous des auspices favorables. Il y a en Europe une detente monetaire evidente et probablement definitive: c'est d'abord la reduction du fauc prive d'escompte en Angleterre a 4 5/8 pourcent, suivi bieuto: d'une reduction du tans de la Banque d'Etat de 6 a 5 0/0 malgre quoi la reserve de la banque a ete protee celts sormaine de. Il ya eu depuis il est vrai, une reprise du taux prive a 5 0/0 mais caluloin n'a pas tarde a revenir a 4 3/1. De son cote, la Banque d'Allenmagne qui avait le plus eu a fouffrir de la disette de numeraire a aussi ramene sou taux de 7 a 6 0/0.

Sur notre place, la situation monetaire profite natureillement de la detente en Europe, L'Egypte se trove, en outra, particullierement avantague par la prosperite croissante de son agriculture et de sono commerce, comme cala results a l'evidence de la statistique des dous: nes pour les entrees et les sorties en 1906. Tandis qu'en 1905 les importations de L.E. 1,203,791 l'ances qui vient de s'ecou'er se signa'e par un excedent de L.E. 866,483 en faveur des sorties. En effet, les importations ont ete en 1906 de L.E. 24,010,795 contre L.E. 21,564,079 en 1905 et les exportations de L.E. 24,877,280 contre L.E. unit une augmentation de L.E. 2,444,719 aux entrees et de L.E. 4,516,995 aux sorties. Ou voit parce bref et eloquent expose que la situation de l'Egypte ne saurait etre plus florissante. Dans noter derniere chronique nous avonx par edu mouvement de l'or, qui etait egalment tout a l'avantage du pays. Il resort de bes cons'atations que l'Egypte est exceptionnellement prospers et que par suite la hause des valeurs egyptiennes repose sur des bases serieuses. mais, encore une fois, il y a un choix a faire et de la depend l'avenir. Salono que les capitalistes auront dirige leur preference sur les titres solides ou sur ceux que chanffe ha specula ion dans un but facile a comprendre, nous aurons un marche sain et regulier on constamment tiraille par les manipulations de cortaines coteries.

div.head: CAUGHT BY THE GRIP--RELEASED BY PE-RU-NA.
div.p: La Grippe Is Epidemic Catarrh.
LA GRIPPE spares no class or nationality. The cultured and thte ignorant, the aristocrat and the pauper, the masses and the classes are all subject to la grippe. None are example-all are liable.
La grippe is well-named. The original term, la grippe, la French, but it has been shortened by the busy American to one word "grip."
Without any intention of doing so, a new word has been coined which describes the disease exactly.
The ailment clings to the patient as tenaciously as if some terrible giant had clutched him in a fatal clasp.
Men, women, and children- whole towns and cities are caught in the baneful grip of this terrible monoster.
Have you the grip? Or, rather has the grip caught you? If so, read the following letters.
These testimonials will show you the quickest and been means of ridding yourself of this tenacious disease and its after-effects.

"Last winter I was ill with pneumonia after having la grippe. I took Peruna for two months, when I became quite well, and I can say that nay one can be cured by it in a reasonable time and at little expense.
"Every time I take a cold, I take some Peruna which makes me well again.
"I also advised it for my daughter who was so ill with procrastination that she could not follow her trade of dress-making.
"A bottle of Peruna made such a change in her that she has been able to follow her trde every since.

"I also induced a young lady, who was all rundown and confined to the house, to take Peruna and after taking Peruna for three months she is able to follow her trade of tailoring. "I can recommend Peruna for all such who are ill and require a tonic."

Mrs. Jennie W. Gilmore, Box 44, White Oak, Ind. Ter., formerly Housekeeper for Indiana Reform SChool for Boys, writes:

Pe-ru-na--A Tonic After La Grippe.
Mrs. Chas. E. Wells, Sr., Delaware, Ohio, writes: "After a severe attack of la grippe, I took Peruna and found it a very good tonic."
Judge Horatio J. Gosa, Hartwell, Ga., writes "I had a severe spell of la grippe which left me with systemic catarrh. A friend advised me to try Peruna. The third bottle completed the cure."

Robt. L. Madison, A.M. Principal of Cullowhee High School, Painter, N.C. is chairman of the Jackson Country Board of Education. He ahs for nearly six years been teaching in Painter.
He is writer of occasional verre and has contributed to a number of leading papers and magazines,-religious, educational and secular.
In speaking of Peruna, Mr. Madison says:

"I am hardly ever without Peruna in my home. It is the most effective medicine that I have ever tried for la grippe. "It also cured my wife of nasal catarrh. Her condition at one time was such that she could not at night breathe through her nostrils.
"In consequence, an inflamed condition of the throat was brought about, getting worse and worse, and yielding to no remedy until Peruna as tried."
For special instructions, address Dr. Hartman, President of the Hartman Sanitarium, Columbus, Ohio.

For special directions everyone should read "The Ills Of Life" a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty-fix shilliings.
Those wishing direct correspondecne with Dr. Hartman and can wait the necesassry delay in receiving a reply should address Dr. S.B. HARTMAN, Columbus, Ohio, U.S.A.
The following wholesale druggist will supply the retail drug trde in Alexandria, Egypt E DEL MAR.
Alexandria, Egypt.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."

div.p: Societe anonyme constituee le 23 janvier 1906 at autorisse par decret Khedivial du 14 Fevrier 1906, public au Journal Official du Couver Egyptien le 24 Fevrier 1908.
CAPITAL: 15,000,000 de francs
800,000 actions de Capital de 250 Francs chacune
80,000 actions de Dividende sans designation de valeur.
SOUSCRIPTION A 60,000 ACTIONS DE CAPITAL NOUVELLES

En verte des pouvoirs qui lui sont confe ete par l'article 8 des Statuts, le Conseil d'Administation par deliberations eu date des 26 Novembre, 21 Decembre 1906 et 16 Janvier 1907, a decide de porter le capital a:
30,000,000 de fracs
par l'emission de 60,000 actions de capital nouvellles et a detemine les conditions de cette augmentation de capital.
Ces actions numerotees de 60,001 a 120,000 seront smieses jouissance ler Janvier 1907.
E les auront les memes droits et avanta es les actions de capital existances.
DROIT DE SOUCRIPTION
1. SOUSCRIPTIONS PRIVILECIES ET IRREDUCTIBLES.
Tout prteur de DEUX ACTIONOS anciennes (capital on dividende) a le droit de souscrize une action de capital nouvelle.
2. SOUSCRIPTION EVENTUELLES ET REDUCTIBLES.

Les actions nouvelles. pour lequelles ete droit de prefference n'aura pas ete exerce, serout repartissentre les actionnaires anciencs qui les reclamerout par une souscription speciale eventuelle et reductible.
Ces actions eront reparties au prorats des anciene titres posseddee par les souscripteurs sans que la limite indulquee par eux dans leurs souscriptions reductibles puisse etre depasse.
PRIX DE LA SOUSCRIPTION
Le prix de la souscription est fixe a 251 fran par titre, payables de la maniere suivants:
Frs. 63,50 en souscrivant

Les souscriptions en retard d'effectuer ce dernier versement serout possibles d'un interest de 5% l'an, a partir de la date de sou exigibilite, nonobatant les autres atipulations le l'article 9 des statuts.

Les titulaires ou portuers des actions anciennes (capital ou dividende) pourroont user de leur dernit de preference en taissant estampiller leurs titres du samedi 26 Janvier au samedi 9 Fevrier inclus aux banques ciapres designees"
AU CAIRE: a la National Bank of Egypt

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.
